title: 114_hr1444
content: The "Commonsense Contracting Act of 2015" prohibits reverse auctions for covered contracts to improve procurement by increasing competition and opportunities for small businesses. The "Commonsense Contracting Act of 2015" prohibits the use of reverse auction methods for covered contracts under specific sections, and decisions regarding the use of reverse auctions are the responsibility of the contracting officer. The "Commonsense Contracting Act of 2015" prohibits the use of reverse auction methods for covered contracts, with decisions on evaluation criteria, vendor inclusion, and winner selection being the contracting officer's responsibility. Training on reverse auction methods is required for officers supervising such procurements. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 prohibits awarding covered contracts using reverse auction methods if only one offer is received or if offerors cannot submit revised bids with lower prices. Federal agencies must evaluate offers as technically acceptable or unacceptable and cannot misinform offerors about price rankings during the award process. If a Federal agency uses a third-party agent for awarding contracts through reverse auction, they must ensure that inherently governmental functions are not performed by private contractors, and that information on past contract performance is shared in compliance with regulations. When using a third-party agent for contract awards, disputes between the agent and offerors cannot be used to disqualify offerors as responsible sources or restrict their ability to compete for contracts. The term 'contracting officer' is defined in section 2101(1) of title 41, United States Code. A 'covered contract' includes contracts for design and construction services, goods to protect Federal employees, or other goods/services awarded based on factors other than price and technical responsibility. Design and construction services include site planning, architectural and interior design, engineering system design, construction work for projects, supply of construction materials, public building construction, and architectural and engineering services as defined in title 40, United States Code. In procurement, a reverse auction involves offerors competing by submitting offers for a contract with the ability to revise offers with lower prices.
